{{unreferenced|date=January 2012}} {{original research|date=January 2012}} {{distinguish2|the [[Conservative Party (UK)|UK Conservative Party's]] "Stand Up Speak Up" platform}} [[Image:standupspeakup-wristband.jpg|frame|right|The Stand Up Speak Up Wristband]]<!-- FAIR USE of standupspeakup-wristband.jpg: see image description page for rationale --> '''Stand Up Speak Up''' is a [[Europe]]-wide campaign that was launched in January 2005 by the [[France|French]] [[Football (soccer)|Football]] player [[Thierry Henry]] following an increase in reports of [[Racism in football|racist incidents in football]] across Europe. Together with [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] and other top European players, he protests against this continuing problem inviting football fans to voice their opposition to [[racism]].
The symbol of the campaign is two interlocked [[wristband]]s, one black, and one white. About 5 million of these wristbands have been sold all over Europe. The wrist bands are no longer being sold and there is no intention to reproduce them. All the funds raised are passed on to a central Stand Up Speak Up fund that will look to support initiatives that aim to combat racism in football through a variety of programmes and initiatives, that raise awareness, challenge behaviour and strive to change attitudes. This successful campaign included footballers such as [[Thierry Henry]], [[Rio Ferdinand]], [[Wayne Rooney]], [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] and [[Adriano Leite Ribeiro|Adriano]].
Controversy sparked when [[Gary Neville]] claimed Nike were only involved for commercial gain and not their anti-racism stance. This carried over into a match against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] as Neville and [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] team mate [[Paul Scholes]] refused to wear the different anti racism tracksuit top that players from both sides wore.
